Future Ready Digital India Introduction • Digital infrastructure is critical to India’s growth story. • With over 117 crore telecom users and more than 82 crore internet subscribers, India is one of the fastest-growing markets for digital consumers. Digital India progress • India is pioneering the concept of digital public goods that enhance the ease, transparency and speed with which individuals, markets and governments interact with each other. • Applications are transforming the way we make payments, withdraw our PF, get passport and driving licence and check land records. • Children have access to QR-coded textbooks across state boards and languages. • Beneficiaries of government schemes have money transferred directly into their bank accounts. • There is an opportunity for India to embark on digital diplomacy — to take its made-in-India digital public goods to hundreds of emerging economies across the world. Concerns / Challenges • The digital divide takes form in rich-poor, male-female, urban-rural etc segments of the population. • Digital illiteracy, poor infrastructure and lack of coordination among various departments. • Slow adoption of new technologies. • Rampant use of unlicensed and pirated software that are easy targets for malware. Insights Mindmap www.insightsonindia.com Page 2 InsightsIAS • Lack of uniform security protocol and standards used across various electronic devices. • Cybersecurity challenge in ensuring end-to-end protection of data throughout the whole ecosystem. Government Initiatives • India has tried to bridge the digital divide gap by enacting some programmes like o Digital India, o efforts to make India a cashless economy, o Pradhan Mantri Grameen Digital Saksharta Abhiyan (PMGDISHA) aimed at spreading digital literacy among the rural population. Way Forward • To bridge the digital divide, there is a need to accelerate execution of digital India initiative. • Easing of regulations to allow interoperability of wallets to ensure easy transfer of funds for merchants as well as for consumers. • Developing robust rural digital infrastructure and ecosystem. • Enhancing the digital literacy through various platforms. • To achieve the goal of a $1 trillion digital economy requires global standard cyber laws. • By scaling up investments in digital infrastructure, and increased collaboration with local and global entrepreneurs, India can expand its role in the growing global market for digital information- technology services.
